FilipinoMartialArts.name: Filipino Martial Arts

image.attribution: Marines from Arlington, VA, United States, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Members of the Philippine Marine Corps demonstrate martial arts training techniques.

description: Filipino Martial Arts focus on weapon-based combat using sticks, blades, and improvised weapons. Training often starts with weapons before moving to empty-hand techniques.
These systems developed in the Philippines through centuries of warfare and cultural exchange, emphasizing adaptability and real-world application.
Students learn stick fighting, knife defense, footwork, and coordination, while training timing, distance control, and reflexes.
People practice Filipino Martial Arts for self-defense, coordination, and practical weapon awareness.
FilipinoMartialArts.competition_format: Sparring and point-based drills with weapons
benefits: Teaches practical self-defense against armed opponents.

HistoricalEuropeanMartialArts.name: Historical European Martial Arts

image.attribution: Cyberguru, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Historical European Martial Arts competitors fencing with longswords.

description: Historical European Martial Arts, often called HEMA, study traditional European combat systems based on historical manuals and texts.
HEMA includes sword fighting, wrestling, and armored combat from medieval and renaissance Europe.
Students train with weapons like longswords, rapiers, and polearms, along with footwork, grappling, and tactical awareness.
People practice HEMA to learn historical combat, improve coordination, and engage in competitive sparring.
HistoricalEuropeanMartialArts.competition_format: Point-based dueling and sparring with protective gear
benefits: Develops strategic thinking and situational awareness.
Provides a physically challenging and engaging practice.

Iaido.name: Iaido

image.attribution: Rodrigja, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

description: Iaido is a Japanese martial art focused on the smooth, controlled drawing and cutting with a sword, typically a katana.
It emphasizes precise movements, timing, posture, and awareness, with the goal of reacting instantly and efficiently to a sudden threat.
Training is mostly solo through kata, which simulate drawing the sword, striking, and resheathing. Some schools include paired practice and kata with a wooden sword.
People practice Iaido to develop discipline, focus, precision, and mental clarity. It is less about combat sport and more about self-mastery and tradition.
Iaido.competition_format: Demonstration of kata, evaluated for precision, posture, and technique
benefits: Improves focus, mental discipline, and situational awareness.
Develops precise sword-handling and body mechanics.
Preserves traditional Japanese sword arts and etiquette.
Encourages mindfulness and controlled, deliberate movement.

Kendo.name: Kendo

image.attribution: Harald Hofer, CC BY-SA 2.0 AT <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/at/deed.en>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Two kendo practitioners performing taiatari (body clash) during a match.

description: Kendo is a Japanese martial art based on sword fighting using bamboo swords. It emphasizes discipline, respect, and strong spirit.
Kendo developed from traditional samurai sword training and was adapted for safe practice and competition.
Students learn strikes, footwork, posture, and timing while wearing protective armor.
People practice Kendo to build focus, confidence, and mental discipline through structured training.
Kendo.competition_format: Point-based matches using strikes to target areas

Kenjutsu.name: Kenjutsu

image.attribution: Nguyen Thanh Thien, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Kenjutsu practitioners demonstrating traditional sword techniques.

description: Kenjutsu is a traditional Japanese martial art focused on sword combat, teaching techniques used by samurai in historical battle.
Kenjutsu predates modern arts like Kendo and is practiced through kata and controlled partner training.
Students learn cutting techniques, footwork, posture, awareness, and historical weapon handling.
People practice Kenjutsu to study traditional swordsmanship and Japanese martial culture.

OkinawanKobudo.name: Okinawan Kobudo

image.attribution: Мирутенко, CC BY 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Igor Mirutenko attacking in the men's category kumite at the World Traditional Okinawan Kobudo Championship 2019.

description: Okinawan Kobudo is a weapon-based martial art using traditional farming and household tools.
It developed in Okinawa alongside Karate and focuses on preserving traditional weapon techniques.
Students train with weapons like the bo staff, sai, nunchaku, and tonfa, developing precision and flow.
People practice Okinawan Kobudo to improve coordination, discipline, and understanding of traditional weapons.
